explanation:
To find θ opposite the 10 cm side with adjacent 7 cm, the correct ratio is \( \tan\theta = \frac{10}{7} \). The student calculated \( \sin\theta \), which requires \( \frac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}} \). 

The student likely identified the 10 cm side as opposite θ but incorrectly treated the 7 cm side as the hypotenuse instead of the adjacent. This led them to compute \( \sin\theta = \frac{10}{7} \), ignoring that the hypotenuse must be longer than either leg. The error stems from mislabeling the adjacent side as the hypotenuse, directly aligning with the misconception of confusing adjacent/opposite roles. 

This differs from "believes any non-hypotenuse side is opposite," as the student specifically misassigned the hypotenuse role to a leg rather than mislabeling which leg is opposite. The error is rooted in side-identification, not general ratio selection.
